events.title: Jab We Code
events.description: A unique coding contest where teams of two switch contests midway and strategize together in the final phase. The final score is based on combined contest performance.
events.longDescription: Jab We Code is a unique programming contest that tests teamwork, adaptability, and strategic decision-making. Teams of two begin by solving separate contests (Contest A and Contest B) for 30 minutes before discussing their progress and swapping challenges. After another 30 minutes, they strategize once more before entering the final 20-minute phase, where both contests are open, and members decide who tackles which problem. The final ranking is determined by the combined scores of both contests. The top three teams win cash prizes.
rules: Rule 1: Teams consist of two members
Rule 2: Each member starts solving a separate coding contest
Rule 3: After 30 minutes, a 5-minute discussion is allowed before switching contests
Rule 4: After another 30 minutes, teams get a final 5-minute discussion
Rule 5: The last 20 minutes allow both members to work on separate contests simultaneously
Rule 6: The team‚Äôs total score determines the winners

events.title: Optimized Minds - Machine Learning
events.description: Teams choose one of three problem statements and develop an optimized machine learning solution using provided datasets. Solutions are judged on accuracy, efficiency, and innovation.
events.longDescription: Participants will work on one of three given problem statements, using relevant datasets to build the most optimized machine learning model. Teams will be judged based on the efficiency of their models, accuracy of predictions, and innovation in approach. The competition lasts three hours, during which teams analyze data, develop models, and present their findings. Judges will assess optimization and performance metrics to determine winners. The best-performing team for each problem statement wins ‚Çπ2000.
rules: Rule 1: Teams of 1 to 3 members
Rule 2: Each team selects one problem statement from the given options
Rule 3: Relevant datasets will be provided for analysis
Rule 4: Solutions must prioritize accuracy, efficiency, and innovation
Rule 5: Judges will evaluate based on model performance and optimization
Rule 6: One winning team per problem statement (‚Çπ2000 prize per winning team)

events.title: Hera Pheri 3.0
events.description: A three-round event combining a treasure hunt, logical reasoning quiz, and a final "Potli" hunt to determine winners. Tests problem-solving, strategy, and teamwork.
events.longDescription: This event consists of three rounds. The first is a treasure hunt, where teams solve clues to reach different campus locations. The top 10 teams move to a quiz round, where logical questions determine the final four teams. The last round is a "Potli" hunt, where teams search for hidden potlis containing different rewards. The team that finds the golden potli wins ‚Çπ5000, with runner-up receiving ‚Çπ3000. This event emphasizes problem-solving, teamwork, and quick thinking.
rules: Rule 1: Teams must complete the treasure hunt to qualify for the quiz round
Rule 2: Top 10 teams from the treasure hunt advance to the quiz round
Rule 3: Logical questions will be conducted on Discord, affecting team progression
Rule 4: The final four teams search for hidden potlis containing different prizes
Rule 5: The golden potli determines the winning team
Rule 6: Prize pool: ‚Çπ5000 (winner), ‚Çπ3000 (runner-up)

events.title: Ingenious Hackathon 6.0
events.description: The Ingenious Hackathon, a highlight of the annual Ingenium tech fest, is a hub of innovation and coding excellence. Aspiring programmers tackle real-world challenges under time constraints, testing their problem-solving skills, teamwork, and adaptability.
events.longDescription: Welcome to Ingenious Hackathon 6.0, a dynamic 36-hour innovation sprint where creativity meets technology! Whether you're a beginner taking your first steps into coding or a seasoned developer pushing the boundaries of what's possible, this is your space to build, learn, and collaborate. At Ingenious Hackathon 6.0, we believe in the power of ideas. Over the course of the event, you'll form teams, brainstorm solutions, and develop impactful projects around cutting-edge themes like AI/ML, Web3, FinTech, Sustainability, IoT, Open Innovation, and much more. We‚Äôre bringing together developers, designers, product thinkers, and creators to solve real-world challenges, build something meaningful, and connect with an inspiring tech community. Why Join? ‚ú® Turn your ideas into working prototypes. ü§ù Network with industry experts, mentors, and fellow innovators. üèÜ Win exciting prizes and showcase your work to top judges. üìö Learn new skills through workshops and mentorship. üöÄ Build something that could make a difference. No matter your background or experience level, this hackathon is for YOU. So grab your laptop, fuel your creativity, and get ready to build the future.
rules: Rule 1: Only upon the arrival of the entire team can the team start solving the next puzzle
Rule 2: Contact with other teams or people not a part of the event, which in any form may compromise the integrity of the puzzles, is not allowed
Rule 3: The team is allowed to click photos of any resource they may consider useful during the duration of the event
Rule 4: A volunteer will be present with each team to ensure the above rules are followed

events.title: Shaft Tank
events.description: A competition to encourage students to showcase their creativity, innovation, and confidence by pitching their ideas in front of a panel of judges.
events.longDescription: Shaft Tank is designed to bring out the creativity and innovation of students by allowing them to pitch unique ideas or products. Teams of up to 3 members will present their ideas, which can be in the form of an abstract, CAD model, prototype, or a finished product. The event aims to foster confidence and provide a platform for students to showcase their skills. Judges will evaluate pitches based on idea originality, delivery, and potential investment appeal.
rules: Rule 1: Team cannot exceed 3 members
Rule 2: All soft copies related to the pitch must be submitted 48 hours before the event
Rule 3: The idea/product must be something novel
Rule 4: Any reference taken from any place must be mentioned. Plagiarism is strictly prohibited
Rule 5: Pitch cannot exceed 7 minutes
Rule 6: There will be a 10% deduction of investment if the pitch exceeds the time limit
Rule 7: Teams must reach the venue at least 30 minutes before the event. Failing to do so will result in disqualification
Rule 8: Decisions taken by the event heads and panel members will be final

events.title: RC Car Race
events.description: An RC car racing event where teams build and race their own self-fabricated cars on a challenging track with obstacles, aiming for speed, precision, and innovation.
events.longDescription: RC Car Race challenges teams to design and build their own remote-controlled cars for a thrilling competition. Participants must fabricate their cars and navigate a track filled with obstacles like gravel, dirt, ramps, and sharp turns. With strict rules on construction and fair play, the event emphasizes creativity, technical skills, and racing strategy. Teams must fine-tune their vehicles and race against opponents in multiple rounds, culminating in an exciting final lap battle to determine the champion.
rules: Rule 1: Teams must consist of 2-5 members from the same university/college
Rule 2: Participants must be pursuing undergraduate majors
Rule 3: Teams must report 45 minutes prior to the first round
Rule 4: Teams must submit a video of the car working, along with microcontroller code and car specifications
Rule 5: Only one driver is allowed to control the car at the event
Rule 6: No team member (including the driver) is allowed inside the yellow line zone enclosing the track
Rule 7: If a car goes off track, it will be disqualified from the round and event
Rule 8: A 2-second penalty will be given for minor car collisions based on judge‚Äôs decision
Rule 9: A 10-second penalty applies for deliberate bumps causing another car to go off course
Rule 10: Partial off-track violations without collision incur a 2-second penalty
